Fig. 1 XRD pattern of Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3 (a), Rh-Ba/Al2O3 (b) and Pt-Ba/Al2O3 (c) catalysts. The references of γ-Al2O3 face-centered cubic (JCPDS 10-425, solid triangles), BaCO3 witherite (JCPDS 5-378, solid circle), BaCO3 monoclinic (JCPDS 78-2057, empty circle) and Pt face-centered cubic (JCPDS 4-802, triangle) are also reported. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 HRTEM images of Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst. A)-C) STEM-HAADF images; D) HRTEM image. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 HRTEM images of Pt-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst. A) STEM-HAADF image; B) enlargement of A; C) EDX spectra recorded in the areas labeled “a” and “b”; D) and E) HRTEM images. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 HRTEM images of Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst. A)-E) STEM-HAADF image; F) HRTEM images. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 FT-IR spectra recorded upon NO adsorption (NO (1000 ppm) + O2 (3% v/v) in He) at different temperature over Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst. A) 150 °C; B) 250 °C; C) 350 °C. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Amounts of NOx stored and NO2/NO ratio at different temperatures upon NO adsorption (NO (1000 ppm) + O2 (3% v/v) in He) at different temperatures. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 FT-IR spectra recorded upon NO adsorption (NO (1000 ppm) + O2 (3% v/v) in He) at different temperatures over Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst. A) 150 °C; B) 250 °C; C) 350 °C. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) experiments after NOx adsorption at 150 °C (A,B,C), 250 °C (D,E,F) and 350 °C (G,H,L) over Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3 (A,D,G), Pt-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst (B,E,H) and Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst (C,F,L) catalysts. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 15NO Temperature Programmed Isotopic Exchange (15NO-TPIE) experiments after adsorption of nitrites (A–C) and nitrates (D–F) over Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3 (A,D), Pt-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst (B,E) and Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst (C,F) catalysts. Storage conditions: NO (1000 ppm) + O2 (3% v/v) in He at 150 °C (nitrites) or 350 °C (nitrates). Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Temperature Programmed Surface Reaction (TPSR) of nitrates with H2 (A–C) and NH3 (D–E) over Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3 (A,D), Pt-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst (B,E) and Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst (C,F) catalysts. Storage conditions: NO (1000 ppm) + O2 (3% v/v) in He at 350 °C (nitrates). Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Temperature Programmed Surface Reaction (TPSR) of nitrites with H2 (A–C) and NH3 (D–E) over Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3 (A,D), Pt-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst (B,E) and Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst (C,F) catalysts. Storage conditions: NO (1000 ppm) + O2 (3% v/v) in He at 150 °C (nitrites). Graphical abstract In this work the reactivity of Pt-Rh NOx storage-reduction (NSR) catalysts in the reduction of NOx under lean conditions is investigated. It is found that significant amounts of NOx are stored on both Rh- and Pt-based samples at all the investigated temperatures (in the range 150–350 °C). Mostly chelating nitrites are adsorbed at the lowest investigated temperature (150 °C), while nitrates (both bidentate and ionic) at higher temperatures. However, at all temperatures nitrites prevail at the beginning of the storage phase, while nitrates represent the most abundant adsorbed species after prolonged contact. Pt-containing catalysts (either monometallic Pt or bimetallic Pt/Rh) show higher NOx storage capacity than the Rh monometallic sample, possibly due to the higher dispersion of Pt vs. Rh and/or to the higher oxidizing capability of Pt vs. Rh. The stored NOx species show relevant thermal stability, and decompose to NOx and O2 upon heating. In particular, nitrites disproportionate to gaseous NO and nitrates; these latter then decompose to NOx and O2. On the Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst the disproportionation reaction is observed with a higher temperature onset if compared to the Pt-based samples. The analysis of the reactivity of the stored NOx species (probed by isotopic labeling experiments and reduction with H2 and NH3) showed the lower reactivity of the Rh-Ba/Al2O3 sample; however Rh shows activity in the ammonia decomposition reaction to N2 and H2, unlike Pt. The lower reactivity of the Rh-Ba/Al2O3 sample is also pointed out by experiments under cyclic lean-rich conditions. However, the presence of Rh increases the reactivity of the catalyst in the steam reforming of hydrocarbons, especially at high temperature, and accordingly the reactivity of the bimetallic Pt/Rh sample at high temperatures is higher than that of the Pt and Rh monometallic catalysts. Keywords Alumina supported PtRhBa NOx storage reduction Pt vs. Rh reactivity Lean NOx traps 1 Introduction The push for better fuel economy and lower vehicular CO2 emissions greatly increased the lean-burn engines (e.g. diesel) market share, especially in Europe where today diesel cars accounts for more than 50% of new vehicles. However, exhaust gases from these engines contain NOx and excess O2, which renders NOx reduction into N2 impractical over conventional three-way catalysts (TWCs) [1]. Consequently, two main technologies have been developed for mobile lean NOx removal, i.e. selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NOx using urea as a reductant for heavy duty diesel applications [2,3], and lean NOx trap (LNT) catalysts (otherwise known as NOx adsorber or NOx storage-reduction catalysts, NSR) for light duty applications [4]. NSR operation is cyclic: during the lean phase, NOx is trapped on the catalyst; intermittent rich excursions are used to reduce the NOx to N2 and restore the original catalyst surface [5]. Typical NSR compositions include noble metals (Pt, Rh, and sometime Pd) for oxidation/reduction purposes, storage components like BaO and CeO2, and γ-alumina as high surface area support. Among noble metals, Pt is considered to be essential for both the storage and the reduction phase, whereas the role of Rh is not yet fully understood and clarified, although it is generally believed that Rh improves the regeneration and the overall catalyst efficiency [6]. In a previous work of some of us [7] we have investigated the reactivity of Rh in the NOx storage-reduction catalysis. By means of NO2 adsorption studies and of lean/rich cycles with H2 as reducing agents we have concluded that the Rh-based sample exhibits lower NOx storage ability than the Pt-based systems; on the other hand, the role of Rh in the reduction of stored NOx was not completely clear. In this work, we have considered the effect of the addition of Rh in typical Pt-Ba/alumina formulations focusing the attention on the fundamental aspects of the reactions occurring during the typical lean-rich cycling of the catalyst. For this purpose, a Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3 bimetallic catalyst, and the corresponding monometallic Pt- and Rh-based reference samples, have been prepared and deeply characterized by means of BET, XRD, XPS and TEM analysis. FT-IR has been used to characterized the nature of the stored NOx species, while temperature programmed desorption (TPD) and isotopic exchange (TPIE) have been considered to analyze the thermal stability and the reactivity of these species. Finally, isothermal lean-rich cycles using a complex reducing mixture (i.e. H2 + CO + C3H6) have been used to address the reactivity in the NOx removal and the selectivity of the NOx reduction process. 2 Materials and methods Model Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3 (1/0.5/20/100 w/w/w/w) bimetallic sample has been prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of a commercial γ-alumina (Versal 250 UOP) support with Pt(NO2)2(NH3)2 (Strem Chemicals, 5% w/w), Rh(NO3)3 (Sigma Aldrich, 10% w/w) and Ba(CH3COO)2 (Sigma Aldrich, 99% w/w) aqueous solutions. After each impregnation step, the samples have been dried at 80 °C overnight and calcined at 500 °C for 5 h. Model Pt-Ba/Al2O3 (1/20/100 w/w/w) and Rh-Ba/Al2O3 (0.5/20/100 w/w/w) monometallic catalysts have been prepared according to the same procedure. The obtained catalysts have been characterized by BET analysis for specific surface area and pore size distribution by N2 adsorption–desorption at 77 K (BET method, Micromeritics TriStar 3000 Instrument). The metal dispersion has been measured by H2 chemisorption at 40 °C over a pre-reduced catalyst with a TPD/R/O ThermoFisher Instrument. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) analysis has been performed with a Bruker D8 instrument using graphite monochromated CuK α radiation; the diffraction patterns were collected in the 2θ range of 10 - 70° with a step of 0.05° and a counting time of 12.5 s per step. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was carried out using a JEOL 2010 F electron microscope equipped with a field emission source at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Samples were deposited on holey Cu grids. The point-to-point resolution achieved was 0.19 nm and the resolution between lines was 0.14 nm. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a SPECS system equipped with an Al anode XR50 source operating at 150 W and a Phoibos MCD-9 detector. The pass energy of the hemispherical analyzer was set at 25 eV and the energy step was set at 0.1 eV. The pressure in the analysis chamber was kept below 10−7 Pa. The area analysed was about 2 mm × 2 mm. Data processing was performed with the CasaXPS program (Casa Software Ltd., UK). The interaction of NO/O2 with the catalytic surface has been investigated by operando transmission FT-IR spectroscopy and temperature-programmed methods. In the case of FT-IR experiments, NO/O2 mixture (1000 ppm NO + 3% O2 in He, total flow 25 cm3 min−1 at 1 atm and 0 °C) has been fed to the IR reactor consisting in a “Sandwich” IR cell containing the catalyst (15 mg) in form of self-supported wafer. The gases leaving the cell were analyzed by mass spectrometer (ThermoStar TM GSD 301) and chemiluminescence analyzer (42i-HL MEGATEC). Surface FT-IR spectra have been collected with a FT-IR Nicolet Nexus spectrometer with 4 cm−1 spectral resolution and accumulation of 64 scans using DTGS detector. Prior to the experiments, the samples have been conditioned by carrying out a few adsorption/reduction cycles using H2 as reducing agent. This leads to the partial decarbonation of the surface, as discussed in [8]. The thermal stability/reactivity of the stored species has been characterized in a flow microreactor setup by Temperature Programmed Desorption (TPD) and by isotopic labelling experiments with 15NO (Temperature Programmed Isotopic Exchange, TPIE). In the case of TPD experiments, after NOx adsorption at 150-250-350 °C with NO/O2 mixture (1000 ppm NO + 3% O2 in He, total flow 100 cm3 min−1 at 1 atm and 0 °C), the catalyst has been heated up to 400 °C @ 10 °C/min in He, while monitoring the concentration of the gases exiting the reactor with a mass spectrometer (Thermostar 200, Pfeiffer) an UV-NOx analyzer (LIMAS 11 H W) and a micro-gas chromatograph (3000A, Agilent). It is worth to note that the analysis of the reaction products with the mass spectrometer and the gas chromatograph (sampling rate: 150 s) in a parallel arrangement allows to differentiate products like N2 and CO both having the molecular peak at m/e = 28 and thus hardly distinguishable by the mass spectrometer. Thanks to the N2/CO ratio periodically estimated by the gas chromatographic analysis, the deconvolution of the overall MS trace at m/e = 28 into the individual N2 and CO concentrations could be attained. A similar procedure has been adopted for TPIE experiments, but in this case after adsorption of unlabelled NO in the presence of oxygen at 150 °C and 350 °C, the catalyst sample has been heated up to 400 °C @ 10 °C/min under a flow of 15NO (1000 ppm) in He. Feed gases are obtained from calibrated gas mixtures (0.2% v/v 14NO in He; 0.3% v/v 15NO in He, 15N isotopic abundance 98%) containing an inert tracer (Ar). As for FT-IR adsorption experiments, the samples have been conditioned by carrying out a few adsorption/reduction cycles using H2 as reducing agent. Further details on the experimental procedure and setup can be found elsewhere [9]. The reactivity of the prepared catalysts in the NOx removal has been studied by means of lean-rich cycles at different temperature in the 150–350 °C range. During the lean phase, NO / O2 (1000 ppm NO + 3% v/v O2) has been fed to the reactor; then the gas flow was switched to the rich mixture and a flow of H2 (500 ppm) + CO (1500 ppm) + C3H6 (450 ppm) has been admitted to the reactor. The length of both the lean and the rich phases has been set to 15 min. During all the experiments CO2 (1000 ppm) and H2O (2.5% v/v) are present in the flow. Prior to any catalytic run, the fresh catalysts have been conditioned through a series of NOx lean-rich cycles at 350 °C starting from NO/O2 and H2 mixtures. Typically only 3–4 cycles are required to reach stable performances. Then, each test condition has been investigated for several lean-rich cycles, and results herein reported refer to a typical cycle obtained over a fully conditioned catalyst showing stable performances. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphological and structural characterization 3.1.1 Morphological analysis The nominal composition of the prepared catalysts, the specific surface area, pore volume and pore sizes are reported in Table 1 , along with the metal dispersion. Pt-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst shows a specific surface area of 140 m2 g−1 with a final metal dispersion near 60%; Rh-Ba/Al2O3 exhibits a specific surface area of 150 m2 g−1 with a Rh dispersion near 7%. The bimetallic system shows similar morphological characteristics as the monometallic ones; it was not possible to measure the metal dispersion in this case. 3.1.2 XRD analysis Fig. 1 shows the XRD spectra of the freshly calcined samples. From the XRD patterns it is possible to recognize in all the catalysts the characteristic peaks of microcrystalline face-centered cubic γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS 10–425) and of BaCO3 both in the monoclinic and whiterite forms (JCPDS 78–2057 and 5–378, respectively). No peaks related to Pt and Rh metallic phases have been identified, due to the good dispersion of Pt and to the small concentration of Rh. 3.1.3 HRTEM analysis Fig. 2 A-C shows images recorded by STEM-HAADF of the Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst. The bright spots correspond to the noble metal nanoparticles, which exhibit an excellent dispersion over the alumina support. The mean particle size of the noble metal nanoparticles is about 2–3 nm. A representative HRTEM image is shown in Fig. 2D, which confirms the excellent dispersion of noble metal nanoparticles. Given the small size of the noble metal nanoparticles, the EDX spectra does not allow to distinguish between Pt and Rh. Also, it is not possible to get lattice fringe images of the noble metal nanoparticles. In this regard, it is not possible to discuss if the nanoparticles are monometallic or bimetallic. STEM-HAADF and HRTEM images of the Pt-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst are reported in Fig. 3 . Fig. 3A and its enlargement in Fig. 3B show numerous Pt nanoparticles of similar size and extremely well-dispersed. The mean particle size of Pt is about 1–2 nm, indicating a certainly remarkable dispersion of the Pt nanoparticles. In Fig. 3C, the EDX spectra recorded in the areas labeled “a” and “b” are shown. Note that Cu signal comes from the TEM grid. The EDX spectrum of area “a” does not contain any bright spot corresponding to Pt and shows the presence of Al and O, the last coming from the alumina support as well as Ba; this demonstrates that Ba is distributed all over the alumina support. The EDX spectrum of area “b”, in which it is possible to recognize several bright spot corresponding to Pt nanoparticles, shows in addition to Al, O and Ba, signals of Pt, as expected. Finally, Fig. 3D and E shows HRTEM images, where the morphology and dimensions of the alumina flakes are seen. Also in this case, no Ba segregated is observed in any part of the sample. STEM-HAADF images of the Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst are displayed in Fig. 4 A-E. Both individual Rh nanoparticles as well as Rh aggregated nanoparticles are observed. Moreover, comparing with the TEM images of the binary Rh/Al2O3 catalyst (not shown), the presence of Ba does not seem to improve dispersion of the noble metal nanoparticles. Also, barium is not identified occurring as a separate phase and it is likely dispersed in all the sample. Fig. 4F shows a HRTEM image where only the alumina support crystallites are clearly identified. 3.1.4 XPS analysis The results of the XPS analysis are reported in Table 2 in terms of surface atomic ratio. First of all, the atomic concentrations of the noble metals and Ba at the surface of the samples determined by XPS are always lower than those of the bulk. The dispersion of Ba is virtually identical in all samples containing this element (2.3–2.4 %). The dispersion of Rh is also very similar between the different samples containing this element. This could be apparently in contradiction to the TEM results, showing for the Rh/Al2O3 and Rh-Ba/Al2O3 samples the presence of agglomerated Rh nanoparticles. However, given their small dimension, the area of the Rh nanoparticles analyzed by XPS includes all the Rh. In other words, it is not possible to distinguish between isolated Rh nanoparticles and agglomerated Rh since everything is indeed analyzed. 3.2 Characterization of the NOx adsorbed species 3.2.1 NOx adsorption Fig. 5 shows the results (difference spectra) obtained upon NO/O2 adsorption at 150 °C, 250 °C and 350 °C over the conditioned Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3 surface (Fig. 5A, B, C, respectively). The FT-IR spectra recorded during the NOx storage at 150 °C (Fig. 5A) show the formation of chelating nitrites on the barium phase with characteristic bands at 1356 and 1233 cm−1 related to ν sym.(NO2) and ν asym.(NO2) modes, respectively. The concentration of such species increases monotonically during storage. In addition, minor amounts of bidentate nitrates (1556 cm−1, ν(NO) mode) are formed after prolonged exposures, due to the slow nitrite oxidation [10–12]. When adsorption is carried out at 250 °C (Fig. 5B), the FT-IR spectra show the formation mainly of chelating nitrites (main band at 1220 cm−1) at low exposure times. Nitrites continue to increase with time on stream and, in parallel, both ionic nitrates (νasym.(NO3) mode split at 1403 and 1350 cm−1 and ν sym. (NO3) mode at 1040 cm−1) and bidentate nitrates at 1546 cm−1 start to form. After long exposures the band at 1220 cm−1 related to nitrites goes through a maximum and then starts to decrease in intensity due to the oxidation of nitrites into nitrates. On the other hands, the bands characteristic of ionic nitrates increases markedly. The parallel decrease of the band at 1546 cm−1 suggests the transformation of the bidentate nitrates into ionic ones, witnessing for a progressive transfer of alumina surface species to barium oxide bulk species. Finally, the small band near 1755 cm-1 might be associated to the formation of N2O4 species [13]. Fig. 5C shows the FT-IR spectra recorded as a function of time on stream during the NOx storage at 350 °C. In this case, both nitrites and nitrates are almost simultaneously formed at the initial stages of adsorption. Upon increasing the exposure time, the nitrite species decrease and eventually disappear while the nitrate bands continue to increase. Also in this case the band of bidentate nitrates shows a maximum, while those of ionic nitrates grow monotonically with time, coherently with their formation mechanism and related kinetics. At saturation, only ionic nitrates are present on the surface along with minor amounts of N2O4 species. The gas phase measurements carried out during the storage (not shown for the sake of brevity) show that the storage temperature has also a clear effect on the overall NOx storage capacity and on the NO oxidation capacity of the catalyst (i.e. on the amount of NO2 produced at steady state), as shown in Fig. 6 A and 6B, respectively. At 150 °C the amounts of the stored NOx (nitrites) are near 1.53 10−4 mol gcat -1 (see Fig. 6A), while negligible amounts of NO2 are observed in the gas phase at the end of the lean phase (Fig. 6B). Upon increasing the temperature, both the concentration of NO2 at steady state and the storage capacity increase, this latter reaching a maximum of 3.89 10−4 mol gcat -1 at 350 °C (Fig. 6C). The same experiments have been carried out over both monometallic Pt-Ba/Al2O3 and Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalysts. In the case of the Pt-Ba/Al2O3 sample the results are not reported here since they have been already discussed in previous papers of some of us [10–12]. Very similar results to those presented in the case of the bimetallic sample have been obtained, i.e. formation of surface nitrites only at low temperature (150 °C); formation of nitrites and nitrates (i.e. both ionic and bidentate) at 250 °C, with slow transformation of nitrites into nitrates after prolonged exposures; nitrite formation only at the early stages of adsorption at 350 °C while the bands of nitrates markedly increased with time on stream [10–12]. Notably, the nitrites / nitrates transformation with temperature has also been observed by Dupré et al. [14] over a commercial NSR material under realistic conditions, thus confirming the representative behavior of the investigated model samples. Finally, as shown in Fig. 6, the Rh-Ba/Al2O3 sample exhibits higher storage capacity and NO oxidation activity if compared to Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3. In the case of Rh-Ba/Al2O3, at 150 °C NOx adsorption results mainly in the formation of nitrites (bands at 1360 and 1234 cm−1), whose concentration grows with time on stream (Fig. 7 A). In addition, bidentate nitrates (1559 cm−1) are also seen after long exposure times. However, at variance to what observed over Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3, also ionic nitrates (1394 and 1368 cm−1) and monodentate nitrates [15] (band at 1442 cm−1) are likely formed in small amounts at this temperature. At 250 °C (Fig. 7B) the formation of both nitrites and nitrates (i.e. ionic and bidentate nitrates) is evident; of note, differently from the case of Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3, both nitrites and nitrates increase monotonically with time on stream, and no transformation of nitrites and bidentate nitrates into ionic nitrates can be observed. Finally, at 350 °C (Fig. 7C) the behaviour of Rh-Ba/Al2O3 is similar to that of Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3 and Pt-Ba/Al2O3, in that nitrite species are observed only at a very short exposure time which rapidly evolve to ionic and bidentate nitrates. The transformation of bidentate nitrates into the ionic ones is also apparent. As compared to the Pt-containing catalysts, the Rh-based sample shows lower NOx storage capacity and NO oxidation capability (Fig. 6). To resume, the FT-IR data collected over the three different catalytic systems show that the adsorbed NOx species exhibit similar features. In fact, in all cases the NO/O2 adsorption at low temperature (150 °C) results almost exclusively in the formation of nitrites; upon increasing the temperature, nitrates are also formed. However, nitrites prevail at the beginning of the storage phase while nitrates represent the most abundant adsorbed species after prolonged contact. Of note, the transformation of nitrites into nitrates is slower over Rh-based catalysts, indicating the lower oxidation capability of Rh if compared to Pt. 3.2.2 Thermal stability of the stored NOx species The thermal stability of stored NOx species was evaluated by temperature-programmed desorption (TPD), after adsorption at 150 °C, 250 °C and 350 °C (see above). TPD profiles obtained after storage at 150 °C over the Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst are plotted in Fig. 8 A. Inspection of Figure shows that the temperature onset for NOx release is near 125 °C, i.e. slightly lower with respect to the adsorption temperature. Two NO desorption peaks are clearly observed with maxima centred at 250 °C and 470 °C. Notably, the high-temperature peak is accompanied by the evolution of O2. The TPD profile of the monometallic Pt- and Rh-based catalysts are very similar to that of bimetallic Pt/Rh sample, although with different intensity (see Figs. 8B and C). In fact, in all cases a NO desorption peak is observed at low temperature, with a maximum centred near 250 °C in the case of the Pt-based monometallic system and near 300 °C in the case of the Rh-based sample. In both cases a high-T desorption peak is observed, accompanied by the evolution of O2. The presence of two desorption steps likely indicates the decomposition of NOx adsorbed species having different stabilities. The observation that at low-temperature only NO is released whereas at high temperature the NO evolution is accompanied by O2 might be explained considering the disproportionation of nitrites to nitrates species [16] according to reaction (1): (1) 3 Ba(NO2)2 → Ba(NO3)2 + 2 BaO + 4 NO↑ Nitrites disproportion is responsible for NO release at low temperatures. Nitrates are then decomposed at higher temperatures into NO and O2, according to reaction (2): (2) Ba(NO3)2 → BaO + 2 NO+3/2 O2 and this reaction accounts for NO and O2 desorption at high temperatures. At variance, the TPD profile shows a unique decomposition peak after NOx adsorption at 350 °C on the Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 8G), where nitrates have been formed (see above). NO and O2 evolution is observed, centred near 450 °C. The evolution of small amounts of NO2 is also observed, with a maximum near 420 °C. A very similar behaviour is observed when monometallic catalysts are considered (Fig. 8H for Pt-based catalyst, Fig. 8L for Rh-Ba/Al2O3), where nitrate decomposition leads to NO and O2 peaks with maximum centred near 320–350 °C. It is worth to note that in these cases the N/O ratio of the species evolved during the TPD run is very close to that expected from the decomposition of stored nitrates (N/O = 0.4, reaction (2)). Similar N/O values are obtained in correspondence of the high-T peak seen during the TPD after NOx adsorption at 150 °C (Fig. 8A–C), in line with the decomposition of nitrates formed upon nitrite disproportionation (reaction (1)). When the NOx adsorption is performed at intermediate temperature, i.e. at 250 °C (Fig. 8D–F), the TPD profiles resemble to those of nitrates decomposition in the case of the Pt-containing samples (Fig. 8 D and E), since in these cases mostly nitrates are present on the catalyst surface at the end of the NOx adsorption (see previous paragraph). At variance, in the case of the Rh-Ba/Al2O3 sample (Fig. 8 F), a significant low-T NO desorption peak is also evident, due to nitrite disproportionation. In fact, in this case both nitrites and nitrates are stored upon NO/O2 adsorption at such temperature (see Fig. 5 B). 3.3 Reactivity of the NOx adsorbed species 3.3.1 Isotopic exchange experiments between 15NO and stored 14NOx It has been previously shown that the isotopic exchange reaction between stored NOx species and gas-phase NO is catalyzed by the noble metal [9] and can be used to probe the reactivity of the stored species in the release of gas-phase NO, the first step in the reduction of the stored NOx. To further address the reactivity of Pt in this reaction if compared to Rh and Pt/Rh, 15NO Temperature Programmed Isotopic Exchange (15NO-TPIE) experiments have been performed over mono- and bimetallic catalysts starting from different precursors (nitrites and nitrates). In these experiments, the reactivity of unlabeled stored 14NOx species is investigated by heating the catalyst in flowing labeled gaseous 15NO, and results are shown in Fig. 9 . In the case of unlabeled nitrites stored over the Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 9A), consumption of 15NO is observed between 70 °C and 250 °C, accompanied by a correspondent release of 14NO. A minor high-temperature peak is also observed near 350 °C. The overall NOx concentration trace shows a NO peak in the range 140–350 °C (corresponding to the maximum heating temperature) due to the disproportionation of the stored nitrites, as discussed above. In fact, the onset temperature of nitrites decomposition in Fig. 9 well compares with that observed during TPD of nitrites in Fig. 8. No NO2 is detected at any temperature. The NO isotopic exchange is catalyzed by the metal sites. As discussed in a previous work [9], the exchange reaction involves initially the interaction of unlabeled nitrites stored at a Ba site with a neighboring metallic site (Pt and/or Rh). This leads to the release of unlabeled NO in the gas phase, with formation of a free BaO site and an oxygen species at metal site (reaction 3). This Me-O species oxidizes labeled NO present in the gas phase to give adsorbed labeled nitrite species and restoring the metallic sites (reaction 4): (3) Ba(14NO2)2 + Me → BaO + 2 14NO↑ + Me-O (4) 215NO+Me-O+BaO → Ba(15NO2)2 + Me Reactions (3) and (4) lead to the overal stoichiometry of the exchange reaction (5): Ba(14NO2)2 + 2 15NO → Ba(15NO2)2 + 2 14NO↑(5) Being reactions (3) and (4) catalysed by the noble metal sites, the exchange reaction (5) can be used to probe the reactivity of the noble metal in the NO release. In fact, the NO isotopic exchange is a redox process where metallic centers activate stored nitrites and nitrates that are destabilized and eventually released in the gas phase as NO. Results similar to those obtained in the case of the Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst have been obtained over the Pt-Ba/Al2O3 monometallic catalyst (Fig. 9B), whereas in the case of the Rh-Ba/Al2O3 sample (Fig. 9C) the onset temperature for the isotopic exchange is seen at nearly the same temperature but the process proceeds slowly, so that the maximum in the 14NO concentration is observed at higher temperature (near 230 °C) if compared to the Pt-containing samples. Notably, the exchange reaction (5) occurs for the Pt-containing catalysts well below the onset temperature for the nitrite thermal decomposition pointed out by TPD experiments. A slightly higher temperature onset has been observed for the Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst, indicating the lower reactivity of Rh with respect to Pt in the nitrite exchange. The exchange of the stored nitrates with gas-phase 15NO has been investigated as well, and results are shown in Fig. 9 D–F. A picture very similar to that observed in the case of nitrites is apparent, although the exchange reaction is seen at higher temperatures. In fact, the evolution of 14NO and the consumption of 15NO are observed in all cases at high temperature, starting from 250 °C. In any case the exchange reaction is observed well below the temperature observed for the thermal decomposition of nitrates measured by TPD (Fig. 8). The exchange reaction proceeds in this case up to 350 °C and during the subsequent hold at this temperature. It is worth to note that in the case of the nitrate exchange reaction all samples show a similar reactivity, at variance with that observed in the case of the nitrites, possibly due to the higher temperature involved in the exchange reaction. However, in the presence of Rh the extent of exchange is lower than in the case of the Pt-containing catalysts, hence confirming the lower reactivity of Rh. 3.3.2 Reactivity of the stored NOx species towards reducing agent To further address the reactivity of Pt and Rh, the reduction of NOx species (nitrates and nitrites) stored on the investigated catalysts has been studied by temperature programmed (TPSR) methods. H2 and NH3 have been considered as reducing agents (H2-TPSR or NH3-TPSR, respectively). 3.3.2.1 TPSR of nitrates The results obtained upon the reactivity of nitrate ad-species stored over the bimetallic Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst using H2 or NH3 as reductant are shown in Fig. 10 A and 10D, respectively. When H2 is employed as reducing agent (Fig. 10A), the temperature onset for its consumption is observed near 150 °C. At 200 °C H2 is totally consumed and both NH3 and N2 are observed as reduction products; neither NO nor N2O were detected during the reduction. Initially, H2 is consumed in the reduction of stored nitrates and only ammonia is formed (reaction (6)). Then, when H2 is completely consumed, the so-formed ammonia becomes reactive in the reduction of stored species (reaction (7)), in line with mechanistic suggestions indicating that ammonia is initially formed in the reduction of the stored nitrates and hence acts as intermediate in N2 formation [17]: (6) Ba(NO3)2 + 8 H2 → 2 NH3 + BaO + 5 H2O (7) 3Ba(NO3)2 + 10 NH3 → 8 N2 + 3 BaO + 15 H2O The ammonia profile, indeed, shows a minimum in correspondence to the maximum of nitrogen production. Finally, H2 concentration raises due to the depletion of stored nitrates, nitrogen concentration quickly decays to zero while the ammonia decrease is much slower. At 500 °C the hydrogen concentration is very close to the inlet value (2000 ppm). For comparative purposes, Fig. 10B-C shows also the results obtained in the case of the H2-TPSR of nitrates over the Pt- and Rh-monometallic samples, respectively, already discussed elsewhere [18–20] but here reported for comparison purposes. The reduction profile in the case of Pt-monometallic catalyst (Fig. 10B) is very similar to that of bimetallic Pt/Rh sample, showing similar features and temperature onsets. At variance, over the Rh-monometallic system (Fig. 10C), two main H2 consumption peaks are apparent, a low-T peak corresponding to the formation of NH3 and a high-T peak corresponding to the evolution of N2. The low-T peak shows a higher temperature onset with respect to the Pt-containing catalysts (200 °C vs 170 °C), indicating the lower reactivity of Rh in the reduction of stored NOx. The lack of N2 formation in correspondence of the low-T peak indicates that only reaction (6) is ongoing, in line with the inhibition of H2 on NH3 reactivity with stored NOx [21]. Concerning the high-T peak, this is likely related to the reduction of refractory NOx species stored over the catalyst; in this case N2 (and not NH3) is evolved being the formed NH3 decomposed to N2 and H2 (reaction (8)) at high temperatures over the Rh-containing sample, as detailed below. (8) 2NH3 → N2 + 3 H2 The reactivity of stored nitrates has been studied also using ammonia as reducing agent and the results are reported in Fig. 10D–F. Note that in this case isotopically labeled nitrates are present at the catalyst surface, being obtained by 15NO/O2 adsorption. Accordingly, mechanistic indications could be obtained concerning the formation of the N-containing products (i.e. whether they come from unlabeled NH3 or labeled NOx). Over all the catalytic systems the reduction of nitrates by ammonia is slower since the onset of this reaction is observed at higher temperature than the one with hydrogen, and is fully selective to nitrogen, being this the only detected species. Again, the Rh-monometallic system shows lower activity in the reduction of the stored NOx (higher temperature onset for the reduction). In all cases, the evolution of the three dinitrogen isotopes is observed, with different concentrations. Initially, unlabeled 14N2 and the single-labeled 15N14N species are the most abundant species, while 15N2 is present in lower concentrations. As discussed in [20], this is related to the statistical recombination of labeled and unlabeled N-adatoms present on the metal sites. However, around 300 °C, evolution of 14N2 and of H2 is observed in the case of the Rh-containing samples. Since the stored NOx are isotopically labeled (i.e. 15NOx), this species originates only upon 14NH3 decomposition according to reaction (8). Notably, this reaction is not observed in the case of the Pt-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst, thus indicating the high reactivity of Rh in the ammonia decomposition. 3.3.2.2 TPSR of nitrites The reduction of stored nitrites has also been performed and results are shown in Fig. 11 . When H2 is used as a reductant (Fig. 11A–C), the reaction occurs at lower temperatures than nitrates (Fig. 10A–C); indeed, in these case H2 is consumed below 100 °C with formation of NH3 and traces of N2. Again, Pt-containing catalysts are more reactive than Rh-monometallic one, this latter showing a higher temperature onset for the reaction (near 150 °C vs. 100 °C). The consumption of H2 and the NH3 production follow the stoichiometry of the following global reaction (9): (9) Ba(NO2)2 + 6 H2 → 2 NH3 + BaO + 3 H2O Also in the case of nitrites, when H2 is used as reductant, no NO or N2O are observed among the reaction products. In the case of the NH3-TPSR experiment (11D–F), the desorption of ammonia is observed at the beginning of the experiment. Then, from nearly 120 °C over the Pt-containing catalysts (and near 180 °C in the case of the Rh-monometallic catalyst), a net consumption of ammonia is seen together with the initial formation of N2O and of N2 later on. Nitrogen is by far the most abundant product, with different isotopic composition. At variance with the case of nitrates, the single-labeled isotope (i.e., 15N14N) is initially observed in greater amounts, whereas the unlabeled (14N2) and double-labeled (15N2) species are seen simultaneously and with a short delay with respect to the single-labeled nitrogen [20]. As in the case of nitrates reduction by ammonia previously discussed, also in this case ammonia is decomposed to N2 and H2 at high temperature over the Rh-containing catalysts, leading to unlabeled 14N2. Finally, concerning N2O, only the single-labeled nitrous oxide (15N14NO) is observed at the onset of the reaction, near 100 °C in the Pt-containing catalysts and near 180 °C on Rh-monometallic sample. As discussed elsewhere [20], the initial abundance of the single-labeled product is in line with a SCR pathway for the reduction of the stored NOx operating at low temperatures, involving the coupling of surface nitrites and ammonia. Then, upon increasing the temperature, different mechanisms operate leading to a different isotopic distribution. Also in the case of the reduction of the stored nitrites, the data hence confirm the lower reactivity of the Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst in the reduction of the stored nitrites as compared to Pt-containing samples. 3.4 Reactivity of Pt- and Rh-based samples under lean-rich conditions Aiming to a better understanding of the different catalytic behavior of Rh- and Pt-based catalysts, we have here analyzed the behavior of the bimetallic Pt/Rh catalyst and of the monometallic reference samples under lean-rich conditions at different temperatures (in the range 150 °C–350 °C) using a complex reducing mixture. In the following, only the data obtained at 250 °C and 350 °C will be shown (Figs. 12 and 13 , respectively). Fig. 12A-C shows the gas-phase results obtained during the lean-rich cycles performed at 250 °C over Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3, Pt-Ba/Al2O3 and Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalysts, respectively. Note that in the Figures only a representative cycle is shown, i.e. obtained after catalyst conditioning. In the case of the Pt/Rh-Ba sample (Fig. 12A), upon the lean switch the breakthrough of NO was detected after 30 s. N2O evolution is also seen at the rich-to-lean transition; as reported in the literature [22–24], this N2O peak (referred as secondary N2O) originates upon oxidation by NO/O2 of reductant species left adsorbed on the surface by the previous rich phase. This species are isocyanates, carbonyls, ammonia and/or CHx fragments, and have been observed by FT-IR measurements [25–27]. After breakthrough, the nitrogen oxide concentration increases with time, until a steady state is reached. The NOx storage is accompanied by evolution of NO2 (near 60 ppm) due to oxidation of NO over Pt (Rh) sites. After 15 min, at the end of the lean phase, 2.66 10−4 mol/gcat NOx are stored onto the catalyst surface. Upon the rich phase, the NO concentration is decreased to zero and the reducing mixture (H2 + CO + C3H6) is fed. At the lean-to-rich switch a tailing in the NOx concentration is observed due to the desorption of weakly NOx adsorbed (near 2.68 10−5 mol/gcat); an instantaneous production of N2 and of N2O (this peak is referred as primary N2O) is observed, along with NH3 which is however detected with a delay and with a prolonged tail. At this temperature, ammonia is by far the most abundant reaction product, as seen in Fig. 14 that shows the nitrogen product selectivity calculated during the rich phase. The observed sequence of the reduction products is in line with mechanistic proposals suggesting NH3 as intermediate in N2 formation [17]; at variance, N2O is formed upon reduction of the released NOx upon the rich switch and is related to the presence of not fully reduced noble metal sites [22–24,26,27]. Notably, upon the rich switch, the reductants concentration shows different dynamics. In fact, the H2 and CO concentration shows a delay and then increases to the inlet value (1500 ppm for CO and 500 ppm for H2); at variance, the C3H6 concentration rapidly growth to the inlet value (450 ppm). This indicates that CO and H2 are involved in the reduction of the adsorbed NOx species leading to N2, N2O and NH3, whereas the more refractory propylene reductant is hardly involved at this temperature in the reduction of the stored NOx. The involvement of CO in the reduction of the stored NOx is also apparent from the CO2 peak evident at the beginning of the rich phase. Notably, the steady CO2 concentration measured during the rich phase is slightly higher than that obsrved during the lean phase (and the CO concentration slightly lower): this may suggest the occurrence of the Water Gas Shift (WGS) reaction (10), although to a limited extent: (10) CO + H2O → CO2 + H2 Similar results have been obtained at this temperature over the monometallic Pt- and Rh-based catalysts (Fig. 12B and C, respectively). However, the Pt-Ba/Al2O3 sample shows a slightly higher NOx storage capacity (3.44 10−4 mol/gcat) with respect to the Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst and slightly higher N2 and N2O selectivity (Fig. 14). At variance, the Rh-based sample shows lower activity and only minor NOx quantities could be stored during the lean phase (1.7 10−4 mol/gcat); accordingly the yield of the reduction products is limited. The reactivity of the catalyst samples has also been tested at 350 °C, and results are displayed in Fig. 13. The bimetallic catalyst (Fig. 13A) shows a dead time in NO breakthrough of 110 s; at the end of the lean phase 6.04 10−4 mol/gcat of NOx have been stored. No N2O formation is seen upon the lean switch, suggesting that no reducing species are adsorbed on the catalyst surface. Upon the rich switch, a significant N2 formation is immediately observed, followed by a minor NH3 evolution. Only a negligible primary N2O formation is observed, in line with the effect of temperature on N2O formation [24,25,27]. Accordingly, a much higher selectivity to N2 is obtained at this temperature (see Fig. 14). CO, H2 and propylene are involved in the reduction of the stored NOx species, in fact the concentration of these species shows a dead time after the rich switch. Notably, at the end of the rich phase, when the stored NOx species have been reduced, the outlet C3H6 concentration is lower than the inlet one (450 ppm) whereas the concentration of H2 is much higher (ca. 1600 ppm vs. 500 ppm). That of CO shows a complex behavior, and at the end of the rich phase is slightly lower than the inlet concentration (1500 ppm). These observations indicate the occurrence at this temperature of both WGS (reaction (10)) and steam reforming reactions of C3H6 (reaction (11)): (11) C3H6 + 3 H2O → 3 CO+6 H2 Similar results have been obtained over the Pt-Ba/Al2O3 sample. However, the amounts of NOx stored are slightly lower than over the bimetallic catalyst (4.59 10−4 vs. 6.04 10−4 mol/gcat) and a higher NO oxidation activity is observed during the lean phase. The rich phase shows similar features (and similar selectivity, see Fig. 14), but the reactivity in both the WGS (reaction (10)) and C3H6 steam reforming (reaction (11)) is lower, as pointed out by the higher propylene concentration and lower CO amounts detected at the reactor outlet at the end of the rich phase. Finally, the Rh-based monometallic catalyst (Fig. 13C) shows the lowest activity. In fact, small amounts of NOx are stored during the lean phase (2.74 10−4 mol/gcat) and poor NO oxidation to NO2 is observed. However, the catalyst shows significant activity in the C3H6 steam reforming (reaction (11)), as pointed out by the small propylene concentration detected at the reactor outlet at the end of the rich phase. 4 Conclusions In this work the reactivity of Pt- and Rh-containing NSR catalysts has been analysed in the adsorption of NOx and in their reduction by using different reductants. It has been found that significant amounts of NOx can be stored on all the investigated samples at all considered temperatures (in the range 150–350 °C). The nature of the adsorbed NOx species strongly depends on temperature, being mostly chelating nitrites at the lowest investigated temperature (150 °C) and nitrates (both bidentate and ionic) at higher temperatures. However, even at higher temperatures nitrites prevail at the beginning of the storage phase, while nitrates represent the most abundant adsorbed species after prolonged contact. Bidentate nitrates (essentially on the alumina support) are also transformed into ionic nitrates (coordinated with the barium phase). Pt-containing catalysts (either monometallic Pt or bimetallic Pt/Rh) show higher NOx storage capacity than the Rh- monometallic sample. This may be likely related to the lower dispersion of Rh vs. Pt in monometallic samples, but this is possibly due to the minor oxidizing capability of Rh vs. Pt. In fact, the Rh-Ba/Al2O3 sample shows a lower oxidation capability of both NO to NO2 and of nitrites to nitrates. The stored NOx species show relevant thermal stability. Upon heating, the stored NOx species decompose over all catalyst samples to NOx and O2. However, nitrites initially disproportionate to NO and nitrates; this reaction is observed in both the Pt- and Rh-containing samples, although on the Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst the reaction is observed with a higher temperature onset. Nitrate species then decompose at high temperatures into NOx and O2. The reactivity of the stored NOx species, probed both by isotopic labeling experiments (NO exchange) and upon reduction with different reductants (H2 and NH3), shows differences depending on the presence of Rh or Pt. In the case of isotopic labeling experiments, used to probe the reactivity in the release of NO, a similar reactivity has been obtained over both the Pt-Ba/Al2O3 monometallic sample and the Pt/Rh-Ba/Al2O3 bimetallic catalyst. At variance, a lower reactivity has been observed in the case of the Rh-Ba/Al2O3 sample. This indicates the lower reactivity of Rh vs. Pt. Similar conclusions have been obtained when the reactivity towards reducing species like H2 and NH3 is considered. In fact, the Rh monometallic sample shows lower reactivity if compared to the Pt-containing samples (either monometallic or bimetallic). However Rh shows activity in the ammonia decomposition reaction to N2 and H2, not observed over Pt. Finally, the reactivity of the Rh- and Pt-based catalysts under cyclic lean-rich conditions, i.e. under NOx storage-reduction, has been addressed under realistic conditions. In line with previous data, where the NOx adsorption and the NOx reduction have been separately investigated, the Rh monometallic catalyst showed lower activity if compared to the Pt-containing samples. However, the presence of Rh increases the reactivity of the catalyst in the steam reforming of hydrocarbons, especially at high temperature. Accordingly, at high temperatures the reactivity of the bimetallic Pt/Rh sample is higher than that of the Pt and Rh monometallic catalysts, and this may provide a rationale for the presence of both Pt and Rh in commercial catalysts. coredata.dc:description: In this work the reactivity of Pt-Rh NOx storage-reduction (NSR) catalysts in the reduction of NOx under lean conditions is investigated. It is found that significant amounts of NOx are stored on both Rh- and Pt-based samples at all the investigated temperatures (in the range 150–350 °C). Mostly chelating nitrites are adsorbed at the lowest investigated temperature (150 °C), while nitrates (both bidentate and ionic) at higher temperatures. However, at all temperatures nitrites prevail at the beginning of the storage phase, while nitrates represent the most abundant adsorbed species after prolonged contact. Pt-containing catalysts (either monometallic Pt or bimetallic Pt/Rh) show higher NOx storage capacity than the Rh monometallic sample, possibly due to the higher dispersion of Pt vs. Rh and/or to the higher oxidizing capability of Pt vs. Rh. The stored NOx species show relevant thermal stability, and decompose to NOx and O2 upon heating. In particular, nitrites disproportionate to gaseous NO and nitrates; these latter then decompose to NOx and O2. On the Rh-Ba/Al2O3 catalyst the disproportionation reaction is observed with a higher temperature onset if compared to the Pt-based samples. The analysis of the reactivity of the stored NOx species (probed by isotopic labeling experiments and reduction with H2 and NH3) showed the lower reactivity of the Rh-Ba/Al2O3 sample; however Rh shows activity in the ammonia decomposition reaction to N2 and H2, unlike Pt. The lower reactivity of the Rh-Ba/Al2O3 sample is also pointed out by experiments under cyclic lean-rich conditions. However, the presence of Rh increases the reactivity of the catalyst in the steam reforming of hydrocarbons, especially at high temperature, and accordingly the reactivity of the bimetallic Pt/Rh sample at high temperatures is higher than that of the Pt and Rh monometallic catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Al2O3-supported Pt/Rh catalysts for NOx removal under lean conditions
